head.supplied: Easter Day 1882 ¶ ¶ Because I shall soon finish a small revision of the Australian Rutaceae, I should ¶ especially ¶ like to ask you, dear Mr Holtze, to send me fruits of number ¶ 160 ¶ . ¶ It is...

div.p: GRG 19/391, State Records of South Australia, Adelaide.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end;

div.p:
Ostertag 1882.
In 1882, Easter fell on 9 April.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0.3335in;

div.p:
Da ich bald eine kleine Revision der australischen Rutaceen beendigen werde, lieber Her Holtze, möchte ich Sie ganz besonders . bitten, mir von 160 Früchte zu senden. Es ist ein neuer Baum (oder Strauch?) u. ich werde solchen nach Ihnen nennen, sobald ich Früchte habe, um die Beschreibung zu vollenden. Sie werden die Pflanze leicht erkennen, an ihren Fraxinus (Eschen) ähnlichen Blättern die aber durchsichtig punktiert sind. Die unzähligen weissen kleinen Blumen stehen in gipfligen
gipfelig? Rispen. Schicken Sie mir gefälligst die Früchte pr. Post, wenn solche auch schon vertrocknet sind oder alt jedenfalls verdorrt unter den Bäumen zu finden. Bestens grüssend

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p: Über Höhe, Rinde Vorkommen u.s.w. hätte ich auch gern einige Notizen. Ich sende Ihnen die eben erschienene 8te decade des Eucal. Atlas, u. bitte Sie, solche auch Hr Foelsche zu zeigen. Sie werden dann beide sehen, worauf es beim Sammeln der Exemplare und Schreiben der Notizen ankommt.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 10pt; text-align: end;
font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 10pt; margin-left: 0in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0.3335in;

div.p:
Because I shall soon finish a small revision of the Australian Rutaceae, I should especially like to ask you, dear Mr Holtze, to send me fruits of number 160 .
See M to M. Holtze, 1881 (in this edition as 81-00-00j) and M. Holtze to M, 21 May 1882.
No 'small revision' of the Rutaceae by M has been found. It is possible that M had planned such a revision for his Fragmenta, which however ceased publication with the first part of vol. 12 in December 1882. It is also possible that M was working up the Rutaceae in preparation for the publication of his Systematic census (B83.03.04). It is a new tree (or is it a shrub?) and I am going to name it after you as soon as I have the fruits in order to finish the description. You will recognise the plant easily from its fraxinus-like (ash-like) leaves, but which are marked with transparent dots. The innumerable small white flowers stand together in pointed panicles. Please send me fruits by mail, even if they are already old and dried out, that is, if they are found dried out underneath the trees.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in; font-size: 10pt;
font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 10pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0.4929in;

div.p:
I should also like to have some notes about the height, bark, distribution, etc. I am sending you the eighth decade of the Eucalypt Atlas that has just come out
B82.13.17. and ask you also to show it to Mr Foelsche. From that you will both see how to go about the collecting of the specimens and the writing of the notes.
